{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3574482,"name":"Andrii Bessarab","username":"andriibessarab","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andriibessarab/{size}/258546_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T01:27:54.009Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone!

I’m seeking advice on optimizing our autonomous routine.

Here is a video of what it looks like at the moment. We’re on the blue alliance, team 4951.

Our setup involves using PathPlanner to navigate the robot to the general vicinity of a desired location, followed by a custom command that uses vision to align the robot to a specific pose on the field. However, I’ve encountered two main challenges:

  1. At the start of the routine, PathPlanner seems to alter its direction to align with the “ideal starting position” before following the intended path. This behavior is undesirable, as I simply want it to proceed to the end pose without adjusting to an ideal starting position. Is there a way to prevent this?
  2. When PathPlanner reaches the desired pose (before PID controllers from a different command take over), I don’t want the robot to come to a complete stop. However, setting a non-zero final speed results in the robot drifting uncontrollably at that speed even after the path ends.

Our current auton routine looks like this:

image3055×1676 282 KB

Here is the aligning command.

I’m wondering if there’s a more effective approach. Could this entire process be managed with PathPlanner alone, despite our past challenges with its accuracy? Or, given that vision nearly always sees some tag, is PathPlanner even necessary? Perhaps everything could be handled directly in code.

we use choreo for path generation and pathplannerlib for following, and have found success with just following paths. one thing we do is when we are within a certain radius of the reef, we add vision measurements with very low standard deviations. we also have our cameras positioned in such a way that at least one camera can always see the tag on the reef. also, we run autos with a much lower acceleration than our theoretical max.

We used to do the same thing, with paths and then a vision command. We managed to run a fairly successful 2-coral with it, so if you want to stick with what you’ve got, then what you can probably do is raise your elevator before you get to the reef, as you seem to use up a lot of time waiting there. You can increase the acceleration/velocity of your pregenerated paths, your auto-align should be able to cover any innacuracy that accrues from the faster speeds.

Recently though, we found success in using pure pregenerated paths in Choreo integrated to Pathplanner to get a 3 coral (1xL2 2xL4) by tuning our Autobuilder PID values. Our best configuration was adding more and more P with a little bit of D and we were able to get enough accuracy with just the right amount of time.
